火星2020于美国东部时间上午7：50(太平洋标准时间下午4：50)从佛罗里达州的卡纳维拉尔角出发。毅力搭载在联合发射联盟(ULA)的阿特拉斯V火箭上，火箭发射良好，并部署了第二级，将航天器送入停车轨道，准备启程前往火星，将于2021年2月抵达。
一旦到达火星，着陆器将于2021年2月18日将毅力带到火星表面，到达被称为杰零陨石坑的目标着陆区。火星上的这个位置曾经是一个湖泊，很久以前，当时火星上的大气与我们今天所知的干燥、尘土飞扬和寒冷的环境有很大的不同。之所以选择这里，是因为它是寻找任何可能存在的微生物生命证据的主要地点，因为它包含了火星上保存最完好的河流三角洲沉积物之一。
然而，NASA的科学家们并不指望能够使用坚持不懈的仪器来确认火星上是否存在生命-他们认为他们可以找到强有力的迹象，表明生命所需的条件和物质曾经存在过，但最终的证据可能来自计划在2026年进行的雄心勃勃的火星样本返回任务。这将需要NASA向这颗红色星球发射一枚返回火箭，该火箭将携带一枚火箭，可以从火星表面起飞，携带着坚持不懈在船上收集的样本。然后，它将与欧洲航天局(ESA)发射的月球车会合，然后火星车将一路返回地球，供科学家研究。
除了它的密封的、放射性的核电池电源、环境传感器、相机和一套其他仪器来帮助提取任何保存下来的古代生命证据外，毅力号还配备了麦克风。这是麦克风第一次到另一个世界的表面旅行，这意味着我们可以听到另一个世界的表面听起来是什么样子，这是我们以前从未做过的事情。
毅力号还搭载了火星匠心直升机，这是一架小型无人机，专为首次自主飞行而设计，也是为了取暖，以便在寒冷的火星夜晚生存。它有望在30天内完成最多5次飞行，其中可能包括彩色照片-这是有史以来第一次从空中制高点拍摄的照片。
对于这项具有历史意义的火星2020任务来说，这是伟大的第一步，现在我们将等待和关注其他重要的里程碑，包括大约两周后航天器启动离开地球轨道的发动机，开始漫长的火星之旅。

Mars 2020 departed from Cape Canaveral in Florida at 7:50 AM EDT (4:50 PM PDT). Perseverance was loaded atop a United Launch Alliance (ULA) Atlas V rocket, which had a good liftoff and deployed its second stage which put the spacecraft into a parking orbit as it readies to depart on its trip towards Mars, which will see it arrive in February 2021.
 Once at Mars, the lander vehicle will take Perseverance down to the planet’s surface on February 18, 2021, to a target landing zone found in what’s known as Jezero Crater. This location on Mars was once a lake, long ago when the atmosphere on Mars was quite different than the dry, dusty and cold environment we know today. This has been chosen specifically because it’s a prime spot for finding any evidence of microbiological life that might exist, since it contains one of the best-preserved deposits of a river delta on Mars.
  NASA scientists don’t expect to be able to confirm the existence of life on Mars using the instruments on Perseverance, however – they think they can find strong indications that the conditions and materials necessary for life once existed, but the ultimate proof could come from the ambitious Mars sample return mission being planned for 2026. This would involve NASA launching a return rocket to the red planet, which will carry a rocket that can take off from the Mars surface with samples collected by Perseverance on board. That would then meet up with a rover to be launched by the European Space Agency ( ESA)   which would then make the trip all the way back to Earth for scientists to study.
 In addition to its contained, radioactive nuclear battery power source, environment sensors, cameras and a suite of other instruments to help pick up any preserved evidence of ancient life, Perseverance is equipped with microphones. This is the first time that microphones are making the trip to the surface of another world, and it means we could hear what it sounds like on the surface of another world, something we’ve never done before.
 Perseverance also carries the Mars Ingenuity helicopter, a small drone designed for first-ever self-powered flight, which is also designed to warm itself to survive the cold Martian night. It is set to hopefully make up to five flights in 30 days, could include color photos – the first ever taken from an aerial vantage point.
 This is a great first step for this historic Mars 2020 mission, and now we’ll wait and watch for other significant milestones, including next in around two weeks when the spacecraft fires its engines for its departure from Earth’s orbit and begins the long trip to Mars.

联邦政府周二要求联邦法官判处安东尼·莱万多夫斯基(Anthony Levandowski)27个月监禁，罪名是窃取商业机密。今年3月，莱万多夫斯基承认在离开他的新创业公司的路上窃取了一份与谷歌自动驾驶技术有关的机密文件。这家初创公司很快被优步收购，引发了两家公司之间的一场激烈的法律战，并于2018年达成和解。
政府最初指控莱万多夫斯基33项窃取商业秘密的罪名，每项罪名都与莱万多夫斯基窃取的不同机密文件有关。莱万多夫斯基同意认罪，如果政府撤销其他指控，他将承认窃取其中一份文件。这取决于法官威廉·阿尔苏普(William Alsup)对莱万多夫斯基单一承认的窃取商业秘密行为的适当惩罚。
虽然政府希望将莱万多夫斯基关进监狱两年多，但莱万多夫斯基的律师要求法官根本不要把莱万多夫斯基送进监狱。他们争辩说，一年的家庭监禁，加上罚款、恢复原状和社区服务，是足够的惩罚。他们指出，莱万多夫斯基近年来患了两次肺炎，如果他在狱中抓住新冠肺炎，他将面临很高的风险。
在周二的法律简报中，莱万多夫斯基和政府的律师对莱万多夫斯基的罪行描绘了截然不同的图景。政府将莱万多夫斯基描述为密谋窃取谷歌激光雷达技术的技术规格，这样他就可以把这些技术规格卖给优步，并利用这些文件制造与之竞争的产品。联邦政府声称，莱万多夫斯基甚至在谷歌正式通知他将离开之前，就已经在与优步进行收购谈判。
政府写道，莱万多夫斯基与优步(Uber)接触和谈判的细节支持这样一种推断，即他打算将商业秘密转化为所有者以外的人的经济利益。
相比之下，莱万多夫斯基的律师否认他打算利用这些文件来帮助他的新雇主，也否认他曾经这样做过。
莱万多夫斯基的律师写道，虽然莱万多夫斯基离职后拥有一些谷歌文件从未引起争议，但没有证据表明莱万多夫斯基曾与优步或其他任何人使用或分享谷歌的任何专有或商业机密信息。谷歌聘请了一支由律师和法医组成的大军，仔细检查了优步的设施、服务器、源代码、设计文件和原型--总共安装了12个不同的设备。
律师们指出，联邦调查人员还在寻找不当行为的证据。这些努力都没有产生任何证据表明莱万多夫斯基在离开谷歌的工作后使用了谷歌的任何商业机密，无论是在优步还是在其他任何地方。
莱万多夫斯基的律师辩称，政府曲解了经常被引用的数据，即莱万多夫斯基从谷歌服务器下载了1.4万份文件。
这些文档是使用完全颠覆的源代码控制系统存储的。设置服务器的Waymo工程师作证(用莱万多夫斯基的律师的话说)，为了只检查其中一个文件，像莱万多夫斯基这样的授权用户必须启动签出命令，一次自动下载所有14,000个文件。&#34；同一名Waymo工程师说，我们都会做全面的签入，律师们试图将怀疑归因于此，这让我感到不舒服。(用莱万多夫斯基的律师的话说)，即使只检查一个文件，像莱万多夫斯基这样的授权用户也必须启动签出命令，一次自动下载所有14,000个文件。律师们试图将怀疑归咎于此，这让我感到不舒服。
但政府起诉莱万多夫斯基的案件不仅仅是他查阅了1.4万份文件。政府辩称，作为一名高级管理人员，莱万多夫斯基一开始几乎没有合法理由访问这些文件。联邦政府表示，他第一次也是最后一次从储存库结账发生在2015年12月，也就是他离开谷歌的几周前。根据政府的说法，他必须专门申请凭证才能访问这些文件，几天后，他将所有1.4万个文件复制到了他的个人笔记本电脑上。
除了寻求宽大处理的法律简报外，莱万多夫斯基还包括一封写给法官威廉·阿尔苏普(William Alsup)的私人信件。莱万多夫斯基说，他对自己的行为承担全部责任，但也指出，他的行为已经让他蒙受了很大损失。
莱万多夫斯基说，在过去的三年半里，谦逊、责任和悔恨上了令人精疲力竭的一课。由于我的行为，我的职业声誉被毁了，我的财务状况被抹去了，我失去了很多朋友、合作伙伴和同事。
莱万多夫斯基的父母在很小的时候就分居了。小时候，他和母亲一起住在比利时，而他的父亲则搬回了加州。他的母亲勉强维持收支平衡。莱万多夫斯基写道，从很小的时候起，作为家里的男人，他就感觉到了一种责任感。这种不称职的感觉一直伴随着他成年后，他认为这促成了他强烈的职业道德。
莱万多夫斯基说，他现在意识到，他仓促而激烈地离开谷歌是一个错误。
他写道：我在谷歌度过了许多美好的岁月，致力于改变世界的技术，今天我们都认为这是理所当然的。我现在明白了，我匆忙离开谷歌，缺乏清晰的沟通，为愤怒和怨恨的溃烂创造了一扇敞开的窗口，我对拉里·佩奇(Larry Page)、谢尔盖·布林(Sergey Brin)、塞巴斯蒂安·特伦(Sebastian Thrun)以及我在谷歌的同事们表示难以置信的歉意，对他们来说，我的突然离开是一记耳光。我对失去这些友谊深感遗憾。
莱万多夫斯基说，他的新创业公司，一家名为Pronto的自动驾驶卡车初创公司，旨在维护更高的道德标准。他指出，他的新创业公司没有使用激光雷达，这是他与谷歌法律战的核心技术。
莱万多夫斯基还辩称，他可以通过直言不讳地谈论不道德商业行为带来的危害来履行社区服务。
莱万多夫斯基写道：从我的故事中可以学到很多东西，我希望我能以一种对其他人有启发性的方式分享它，帮助科技生态系统演变成一个公平、公平和正义的生态系统。他的律师提议，作为莱万多夫斯基社区服务的一部分，他坦率地分享自己的不当行为，并谈论随之而来的毁灭性后果，从而给自己上了一堂不该做的事的实物课。

“未经授权的面包”--一个关于越狱难民与物联网设备的故事--是科里·多克托罗(Cory Doctorow)的“激进化”的主要中篇小说，该书刚刚入围了加拿大广播公司(Canada Broadcast Corporation)的国家图书奖“加拿大读者奖”(The Canada Reads Award)。未经授权的面包也在与“拦截”的母公司Theme合作开发电视节目，并与艺术家兼漫画创作者JR Doyle合作，由First Second Books改编的一部平面小说。在获得作者许可的情况下，它出现在下面。
萨利玛发现布朗主义已经破产的方式：她的烤面包机不接受她的面包。她拿着切片放在前面，等待屏幕向她展示竖起大拇指的表情符号，但它却向她展示了令人挠头的脸，并做出了一个柔软的brrt。她又挥动了一下面包。布瑞特。
她把烤面包机关了又开。然后她拔下电源，数到十，然后插上电源。然后她在屏幕上翻找，直到找到为止，等了三分钟，又输入了她的Wi-Fi密码。
早在她走到那一步之前，她就已经确信这是一场失败的事业。但这些都是你在电子设备停止工作时采取的步骤，所以你可以拨打800时说，“我把它关了又开了，我拔下了插头，我把它重置为出厂默认设置和…。”
烤面包机上有一个触摸屏选项可以拨打支持电话，但这不起作用，所以她用冰箱查了查号码，然后打了电话。电话铃响了十七次，却断线了。她叹了口气。又有一位被淘汰了。
烤面包机并不是第一台被淘汰的电器(这一荣誉授予了洗碗机，因为在迪舍尔破产的前一周，洗碗机不再能够验证第三方的盘子)，但它是最后一根稻草。她可以在水槽里洗盘子，但她怎么能在该死的蜡烛上烤面包呢？
为了保险起见，她向冰箱索要有关博朗主义的头条新闻，就在那里，他们的乌云在夜里炸开了。社交聚会上挤满了对日常面包感到愤怒的人。她刺激了一个标题，了解到Boulangism已经是一艘幽灵船至少六个月了，因为安全研究人员就是这样联系该公司的，告诉它，它的所有用户数据-密码、登录、订购和账单细节-都挂在公共互联网上，没有密码或加密。数据库中有赎金纸条，黑客插入的记录要求支付加密货币，以换取博朗主义糟糕的数据处理的肮脏秘密。甚至没有人见过他们。
在过去的一年里，Boulangism的股价下跌了98%。甚至可能不再有布朗主义了。当萨利玛描绘出布朗主义时，她想象着烤面包机空闲屏幕上的法式面包店，上面撒着面粉，木块桌子上堆满了一排排硬壳面包。她想象着一段摇摇晃晃的楼梯，从面包店一直通向一套狭窄的办公室，俯瞰着一条鹅卵石路。她想象过煤气灯。
这篇文章拍了一张博朗主义总部的街景照片，这是一座位于孟买附近浦那的四层写字楼，在街道入口处被一个无人看管的警卫亭围了起来。
布朗主义的乌云已经破裂，这意味着当萨利马的烤面包机询问她将要敬酒的面包是否来自授权的布朗主义面包师时，没有人回答，而它确实是来自授权的布朗主义面包师。在没有回复的情况下，这个偏执的小玩意儿会认为萨利玛是那种邪恶的骗子，他们买了一个打折的布朗主义烤面包机，然后试图食言，插入未经授权的面包，后果从厨房起火到次优吐司(布朗主义能够实时调整其烤面包程序，以适应厨房的相对湿度和面包的陈年，当然它会拒绝烘烤已经变得无法挽救的面包。如果没有这些利润，就不会有多余的资金用于研发，从而产生持续的改进，这意味着几乎每一天都会有Salima和数百万其他Boulangism利益相关者(不仅仅是“客户”)醒来，为他们心爱的烤面包机带来令人兴奋的新固件。
那么博朗主义的面包师合伙人又是怎么回事呢？他们做了正确的事情，签署了博朗主义的执照，对他们的过程进行了检查和质量保证，这意味着他们的面包有完全正确的成分，可以在博朗主义的精密工程设备中完美地烘烤，面包屑和孔隙率处于完美平衡，可以吸收黄油和其他涂抹的黄油。这些有价值的合作伙伴理应让他们对卓越的承诺得到尊重，而不是被想要鲁莽地烤任何旧面包的寻找便宜货的骗子抛弃。
萨利玛甚至在她愚蠢的烤面包机播放解释这些论点的视频之前就知道这些论点，在三次失败的面包授权尝试之后，她这样做了，播放时没有暂停或静音按钮，作为惩罚和再教育活动的组合。
她试图在冰箱里搜索“布朗主义黑客”和“布朗主义解锁码”，但电器粘在一起。Kitchenaid的网络过滤器吞噬了她的查询，并吐出尖刻的“没有结果”屏幕，尽管Salima非常清楚，有一个完整的地下经济致力于未经授权的面包。
她半小时后就要去上班了，她甚至还没有洗澡，但是该死的，先是洗碗机，现在是烤面包机。她找到了她的笔记本电脑，当她拿到它的时候用过，现在几乎不能用了。它的电池很久就没电了，她不得不拔掉牙刷的插头来释放充电器电缆，但在启动它并让它运行数十个软件更新后，她能够运行仍然在四处游荡的暗网浏览器，并进行了一些明智的谷歌搜索。
那天她上班迟到了45分钟，但她早餐吃了烤面包。该死的。
洗碗机是下一个。一旦萨利马找到了合适的论坛，不解锁它就太疯狂了。毕竟，她不得不使用它，而现在它实际上是用砖砌成的。她也不是唯一一个遭受迪舍尔和布朗主义双重打击的人。一些可怜的傻瓜还不幸拥有惠普新闻集团(HP NewsCorp)生产的一系列设备中的一种-冰箱、牙刷，甚至性玩具-由于该公司的云提供商塔塔(Tata)的失败，所有这些设备都已经倒闭。虽然这场失败与迪舍尔/布朗主义的双头对决无关，但每个人都同意这是一个相当不幸的时机。
萨利马发现，迪舍尔和博朗主义的双胞胎崩溃确实有共同的原因。这两家公司都是公开交易的，都有超过20%的股份被全球最大的对冲基金Summerstream Funds Management收购，管理着1840亿美元的资产。Summerstream是一家“激进股东”，其股票回购规模非常大。一旦它在每家公司的董事会都有了一个席位--都是由该公司的初级合伙人加尔特·鲍姆加德纳(Galt Baumgardner)占据的，但来自堪萨斯州的一个非常好的家族--他们都从德勤聘请了同一位专家顾问来检查公司的账目，并建议一个回购计划，让股东从公司获得应有的回报，而不会对公司的运营资本造成太深的影响，从而危及他们的安全。
当然，这一切在数学上都是可以证明的。这些公司很容易负担得起将数十亿美元从资产负债表转移到股东手中。一旦确定了这一点，董事会的受托责任就是投票赞成它(这很方便，因为它们都持有大量的公司股票)，而在数十亿美元之后，这些公司变得精干、吝啬、做好了战斗准备，甚至没有错过所有的钱。
Summerstream发布了一份新闻稿(经常在论坛上引用萨利马现在令人着迷的话)，将整件事归咎于“波动性”和“阿尔法”，并称其为“不幸的”和“令人失望的”。他们相信，这两家公司都将在破产中进行重组，可能是在快速出售给竞争对手之后，每个人都可以在一两个月内开始烤面包和洗盘子。
萨利马不会再等了。她的布朗主义并不是一帆风顺的。在从暗网下载了新的固件后，她不得不取下箱子(切开三个单独的明显篡改的封条和一个大的警告贴纸，可能会同时威胁到触电和起诉，任何愚蠢到忽视它的人都可能同时)，找到一个特定的组件，然后在引导它的同时用镊子把它的两个引脚短路。这会使烤面包机进入测试模式，开发人员已经停用了该模式，但并未将其移除。当测试屏幕出现时，她必须在正确的时刻卡住她的U盘(取下烤面包机的引擎盖，露出一组USB端口、一个显示器端口，甚至一个小以太网插孔，所有这些都是控制它的商用单板PC上的库存)，然后使用屏幕键盘输入登录和密码，当然是“admin”和“admin”(当然是“admin”和“admin”)。
她花了三次尝试才找到了正确的时机，但在第三次尝试时，备用的登录屏幕被海盗固件的粗俗的3D头骨文本艺术动画取代，她微笑着看着-然后当一片文本艺术吐司飘进画面时，她爆发出笑声，被文本艺术头骨愉快地咀嚼成面包屑，面包屑像瀑布一样落到屏幕的底部，形成了移动的小堆。有人为那个滑稽的动画做了大量的物理模拟。这让萨利玛感觉很好，就像她把她的烤面包机委托给了深沉、严肃的工匠，而不仅仅是喜欢与来自愚蠢的大公司的不知名程序员较量的兰多。
当头骨被咀嚼时，面包屑堆积起来，进度指示器从12%上升到26%，然后上升到34%(在那里粘了整整10分钟，直到她准备冒险拔掉那该死的东西，但然后-)58%，以此类推，直到99%的痛苦等待，然后所有的面包屑都从屏幕底部冲上来，通过头骨的嘴巴又出来了，又变成了烤面包，每一块重新组装的块都很快地排成了一排，很快就爆炸了，然后所有的面包屑都从屏幕的底部冲了出来，从头骨的嘴里又出来了，又变成了吐司，每一块重新组装的碎片都很快地排成了一排。闪闪发光的黄油顺着小溪流下。她正抓起手机想拍下这张令人敬畏的海盗装载屏幕的照片，这时烤箱闪烁了一下，然后自己重启了。
几秒钟后，她拿着一片面包对着烤面包机的传感器，看着它的灯变绿，门打着呵欠打开。吃到一半时，她突然产生了一种奇怪的好奇心。她把手举到烤面包机上，手掌伸出来，好像它也是一片面包。烤面包机的灯变绿了，门开了。她一时想试着烤一把叉子、一块纸巾或一片苹果，只是想看看烤面包机能不能做到，但它当然能做到。
这是一种新的烤面包机，一种接受订单而不是发号施令的烤面包机。一个烤面包机，可以给她足够的绳子来上吊，让她烤一块锂电池或一罐发胶，或者任何她想烤的东西：未经授权的面包。甚至是自制的面包。这个想法让她觉得有点恶心，有点发抖。她在书上读到过自制面包，在老剧中看到过，但她不认识真正会烘焙的人
配料被证明是令人难以置信的简单，虽然她的第一个面包看起来像大便表情符号，但它尝起来很棒，仍然是从小烤面包机上热的，如果有什么不同的话，那就是她第二天早上保存并烘烤的切片(好的，肿块)更好，特别是上面有黄油。那天她去上班了，肚子里有一种神奇的、温暖的、烤面包的感觉。
那天晚上她洗了洗碗机。Disher黑客在他们的方法上更加实用，但从他们文件中的URL来看，他们也是瑞典人，这可能解释了极简主义。她去过宜家，她明白了。Disher不需要任何像布朗主义那样的歌舞：她弹出维护盖，撬开USB端口的橡胶垫圈，插进她的棍子，然后重新启动。屏幕上显示了大量的滚动文本和一些隐晦的错误信息，然后重新启动，进入看起来像是正常的Disher操作模式，只是没有关于困扰了它一周的无法联系到的服务器的跳动红色警报。她把洗碗槽里的盘子堆到洗碗机里，每次洗碗机弹奏“新菜式认可”琶音时，她都会感到一阵小小的兴奋。

"Unauthorized Bread"—a tale of jailbreaking refugees versus IoTappliances—is the lead novella in author Cory Doctorow's   Radicalized, which has  just been named a finalist for the CanadianBroadcasting Corporation's national book award, the  Canada Reads prize. "Unauthorized Bread" is also in development for television with Topic, parentcompany of The Intercept; and for a graphic novel adaptation by First Second Books, in collaboration with the artist and comics creator  JR Doyle. It appears below with permission from the author.
  The way Salima found out that Boulangism had gone bankrupt: her toaster wouldn’t accept her bread. She held the slice in front of it and waited for the screen to show her a thumbs-up emoji, but instead, it showed her the head-scratching face and made a soft  brrt. She waved the bread again.  Brrt.
  She turned the toaster off and on. Then she unplugged it, counted to ten, and plugged it in. Then she menued through the screens until she found  , waited three minutes, and punched her Wi-Fi password in again.
  Long before she got to that point, she’d grown certain that it was a lost cause. But these were the steps that you took when the electronics stopped working, so you could call the 800 number and say, “I’ve turned it off and on, I’ve unplugged it, I’ve reset it to factory defaults and…”
 There was a touchscreen option on the toaster to call support, but that wasn’t working, so she used the fridge to look up the number and call it. It rang seventeen times and disconnected. She heaved a sigh.  Another one bites the dust.
 The toaster wasn’t the first appliance to go (that honor went to the dishwasher, which stopped being able to validate third-party dishes the week before when Disher went under), but it  was the last straw. She could wash dishes in the sink but how the hell was she supposed to make toast—over a candle?
 Just to be sure, she asked the fridge for headlines about Boulangism, and there it was, their cloud had burst in the night. Socials crawling with people furious about their daily bread. She prodded a headline and learned that Boulangism had been a ghost ship for at least six months because that’s how long security researchers had been contacting the company to tell it that all its user data—passwords, log-ins, ordering and billing details—had been hanging out there on the public internet with no password or encryption. There were  ransom notes in the database, records inserted by hackers demanding cryptocurrency payouts in exchange for keeping the dirty secret of Boulangism’s shitty data handling. No one had even seen them.
 Boulangism’s share price had declined by 98 percent over the past year. There might not even  be a Boulangism anymore. When Salima had pictured Boulangism, she’d imagined the French bakery that was on the toaster’s idle-screen, dusted with flour, woodblock tables with serried ranks of crusty loaves. She’d pictured a rickety staircase leading up from the bakery to a suite of cramped offices overlooking a cobbled road. She’d pictured gas lamps.
 The article had a street-view shot of Boulangism’s headquarters, a four-story office block in Pune, near Mumbai, walled in with an unattended guard booth at the street entrance.
 The Boulangism cloud had burst and that meant that there was no one answering Salima’s toaster when it asked if the bread she was about to toast had come from an authorized Boulangism baker, which it had. In the absence of a reply, the paranoid little gadget would assume that Salima was in that class of nefarious fraudsters who bought a discounted Boulangism toaster and then tried to renege on her end of the bargain by inserting unauthorized bread, which had consequences ranging from kitchen fires to suboptimal toast (Boulangism was able to adjust its toasting routine in realtime to adjust for relative kitchen humidity and the age of the bread, and of course it would refuse to toast bread that had become unsalvageably stale), to say nothing of the loss of profits for the company and its shareholders. Without those profits, there’d be no surplus capital to divert to R&D, creating the continuous improvement that meant that hardly a day went by without Salima and millions of other Boulangism stakeholders (never just “customers”) waking up with exciting new firmware for their beloved toasters.
 And what of the Boulangism baker-partners? They’d done the right thing, signing up for a Boulangism license, subjecting their process to inspections and quality assurance that meant that their bread had exactly the right composition to toast  perfectly in Boulangism’s precision-engineered appliances, with crumb and porosity in perfect balance to absorb butter and other spreads. These valued partners deserved to have their commitment to excellence honored, not cast aside by bargain-hunting cheaters who wanted to recklessly toast any old bread.
 Salima knew these arguments, even before her stupid toaster played her the video explaining them, which it did after three unsuccessful bread-authorization attempts, playing without a pause or mute button as a combination of punishment and reeducation campaign.
 She tried to search her fridge for “boulangism hacks” and “boulangism unlock codes” but appliances stuck together. KitchenAid’s network filters gobbled up her queries and spat back snarky “no results” screens even though Salima knew perfectly well that there was a whole underground economy devoted to unauthorized bread.
 She had to leave for work in half an hour, and she hadn’t even showered yet, but goddamnit, first the dishwasher and now the toaster. She found her laptop, used when she’d gotten it, now barely functional. Its battery was long dead and she had to unplug her toothbrush to free up a charger cable, but after she had booted it and let it run its dozens of software updates, she was able to run the darknet browser she still had kicking around and do some judicious googling.
 She was forty-five minutes late to work that day, but she had toast for breakfast. Goddamnit.
  The dishwasher was next. Once Salima had found the right forum, it would have been crazy  not to unlock the thing. After all, she had to use it and now it was effectively bricked. She wasn’t the only one who had the Disher/Boulangism double whammy, either. Some poor suckers also had the poor fortune to own one of the constellation of devices made by HP-NewsCorp—fridges, toothbrushes, even sex toys—all of which had gone down thanks to a failure of the company’s cloud provider, Tata. While this failure was unrelated to the Disher/Boulangism doubleheader, it was pretty unfortunate timing, everyone agreed.
 The twin collapse of Disher and Boulangism  did have a shared cause, Salima discovered. Both companies were publicly traded and both had seen more than 20 percent of their shares acquired by Summerstream Funds Management, the largest hedge fund on earth, with $184 billion under management. Summerstream was an “activist shareholder” and it was very big on stock buybacks. Once it had a seat on each company’s board—both occupied by Galt Baumgardner, a junior partner at the firm, but from a very good Kansas family—they both hired the same expert consultant from Deloitte to examine the company’s accounts and recommend a buyback program that would see the shareholders getting their due return from the firms, without gouging so deep into the companies’ operating capital as to endanger them.
 It was all mathematically provable, of course. The companies could easily afford to divert billions from their balance sheets to the shareholders. Once this was determined, it was the board’s fiduciary duty to vote in favor of it (which was handy, since they all owned fat wads of company shares) and a few billion dollars later, the companies were lean, mean, and battle ready, and didn’t even miss all that money.
  Summerstream issued a press release (often quoted in the forums Salima was now obsessively haunting) blaming the whole thing on “volatility” and “alpha” and calling it “unfortunate” and “disappointing.” They were confident that both companies would restructure in bankruptcy, perhaps after a quick sale to a competitor, and everyone could start toasting bread and washing dishes within a month or two.
 Salima wasn’t going to wait. Her Boulangism didn’t go easily. After downloading the new firmware from the darknet, she had to remove the case (slicing through three separate tamper-evident seals and a large warning sticker that threatened electrocution and prosecution, perhaps simultaneously, for anyone foolish enough to ignore it) and locate a specific component and then short out two of its pins with a pair of tweezers while booting it. This dropped the toaster into a test mode that the developers had deactivated, but not removed. The instant the test screen came up, she had to jam in her USB stick (removing the toaster’s hood had revealed a set of USB ports, a monitor port, and even a little Ethernet jack, all stock on the commodity single-board PC that controlled it) at exactly the right instant, then use the on-screen keyboard to tap in the log-in and password, which were “admin” and “admin” (of course).
 It took her three tries to get the timing right, but on the third try, the spare log-in screen was replaced with the pirate firmware’s cheesy text-art animation of a 3-D skull, which she smiled at—and then she burst into laughter as a piece of text-art toast floated into the frame and was merrily chomped to crumbs by the text-art skull, the crumbs cascading to the bottom of the screen and forming shifting little piles. Someone had put a lot of effort into the physics simulation for that ridiculous animation. It made Salima feel good, like she was entrusting her toaster to deep, serious craftspeople and not just randos who liked to pit their wits against faceless programmers from big, stupid companies.
 The crumbs piled up as the skull chomped and the progress indicator counted up from 12 percent to 26 percent then to 34 percent (where it stuck for a full ten minutes, until she was ready to risk really bricking the damned thing by unplugging it, but then—) 58 percent, and so on, to an agonizing wait at 99 percent, and then all the crumbs rushed up from the bottom of the screen and went back out through the skull’s mouth, turning  back into toast, each reassembled piece forming up in ranks that quickly blotted out the skull, and the words   burned themselves into the toast’s surface, glistening with butter that ran down in rivulets. She was just grabbing for her phone to get a picture of this awesome pirate load-screen when the toaster oven blinked and rebooted itself.
 A few seconds later, she held a slice of bread to the toaster’s sensor and watched as its light turned green and its door yawned open. Halfway through munching the toast, she was struck by an odd curiosity. She held her hand up to the toaster, palm out, as though it, too, were a slice of bread. The toaster’s light turned green and the door opened. She was momentarily tempted to try and toast a fork or a paper towel or a slice of apple, just to see if the toaster would do it, but of course it would.
 This was a new kind of toaster, a toaster that took orders, rather than giving them. A toaster that would give her enough rope to hang herself, let her toast a lithium battery or a can of hairspray, or anything else she wanted to toast: unauthorized bread. Even homemade bread. The idea made her feel a little queasy and a little tremorous. Homemade bread was something she’d read about in books, seen in old dramas, but she didn’t know anyone who actually baked bread. That was like gnawing your own furniture out of whole logs or something.
 The ingredients turned out to be incredibly simple, and while her first loaf came out looking like a poop emoji, it tasted  amazing, still warm from the little toaster, and if anything, the slice (OK, the lump) she saved and toasted the next morning was even better, especially with butter on it. She left for work that day with a magical, warm,  toasty feeling in her stomach.
  She did the dishwasher that night. The Disher hackers were much more utilitarian in their approach, but they also were Swedish, judging from the URLs in their   files, which might explain the minimalism. She’d been to an Ikea, she got it. The Disher didn’t require anything like the song and dance of the Boulangism: she popped off the maintenance cover, pried the rubber gasket off the USB port, stuck in her stick, and rebooted it. The screen showed a lot of scrolling text and some cryptic error messages and then rebooted again into what looked like normal Disher operating mode, except without the throbbing red alerts about the unreachable server that had haunted it for a week. She piled the dishes from the sink into the dishwasher, feeling a tiny thrill every time the dishwasher played its “New Dish Recognized” arpeggio.

最近的研究已经追踪到巨石阵的蓝石位于大约300公里(200英里)外的威尔士西部普雷塞利山的采石场。当另一组考古学家研究了曾经埋藏在蓝石下的人的火化遗骸中的化学同位素比率时，这些研究人员发现，其中许多人可能来自公元前3100年至公元前2400年之间的威尔士同一地区。在蓝石到达几个世纪后，古代建筑者建造了萨森石碑。到目前为止，现代学者只能推测这些巨石是从哪里来的。
沙森，也被称为硅石，是一种沉积岩，主要由石英胶结的石英砂(石英就是晶体形式的石英)组成，形成于沙质沉积层中。多亏了侵蚀，萨森巨石现在散落在英格兰南部的各处。史前的英国人用萨森巨石建造像巨石阵和埃夫伯里这样的纪念碑，罗马定居者用萨森砖建造他们的别墅，中世纪的人用萨森教堂和农场建筑。但我们今天在英国所知道的最大的沙森巨石是巨石阵的巨石。
大约99%的平均沙森巨石是二氧化硅，但另外1%含有微量的其他元素，如铝、钙、铁、钾、镁和其他元素。这种额外的物质在不同的沙森来源中是不同的，因为它取决于岩石形成的地面中的矿物。纳什和他的同事们使用这些微量元素作为地球化学指纹，将巨石阵沙皇与其最可能的来源进行匹配。
英国最大的沙森集中地是马尔伯勒唐斯，这是一个位于巨石阵以北25到30公里(17英里)的圆形青草丘陵地区。几个世纪以来，考古学家和古物学家一直认为巨石阵沙皇来自马尔伯勒唐斯，主要是因为该地区就在附近，充满了合适的材料。但这一想法没有经过科学检验，蓝石表明，建造巨石阵的新石器时代的人们拥有一个广泛而复杂的供应网络-以及他们自己的做事理由，这对现代研究人员来说往往是难以理解的。
为了追查莎士比亚的来源，考古学家首先必须解决一个更新的谜团：三块丢失的巨石阵发生了什么？
1797年，中央马蹄铁中的一座三石柱(由两块直立的石头支撑着一块水平门楣的拱形结构)倒塌。一个半世纪后，也就是1958年，一项修复工程将这些巨大的石头重新安放到位-但其中一座名为石头58的立柱在其长度上破裂了。为了帮助将破裂的石头固定在一起，以便它可以站立并支撑其一半的门楣石头，修复人员在石头上钻了三个洞，并插入了金属纽带。项目完成后，他们钻出的三个石芯似乎消失得无影无踪。
2018年，其中一名修复者罗伯特·菲利普斯(Robert Phillips)将一个破碎但完整的核心从Stone 58送回了英国。2019年，索尔兹伯里博物馆发现了第二个岩芯的一部分，但仍有1.5个石芯在某个地方。来自菲利普斯核的样本使纳什和他的同事有机会将石头58的化学成分与来自英国各地遗址的萨森巨石进行比较。
事实证明，这场比赛与过去500年来不同研究人员的假设一模一样。唯一与Stone 58匹配的巨石来自马尔伯勒唐斯东南部的一个地点：威尔特郡的西森林，位于巨石阵以北约25公里(16英里)，距离大多数研究人员寻找新石器时代萨森采石场的地方仅3公里(2英里)。西部森林是一个6平方公里(4平方英里)的高原，部分地区树木繁茂，点缀着数千年采石业的大型萨森巨石和矿坑。
纳什和他的同事们写道：“西森林位于新石器时代早期活动的集中地，靠近埃夫伯里，无数的长长的手推车，以及克纳普山有堤坝的围栏，”纳什和他的同事们写道。几千年前，许多树林都是开阔的农田，很可能养活了建造巨石阵和埃夫伯里并在附近的杜灵顿城墙享用美食的人。从西森林，古代建筑者可能将莎草拖到佩西谷，沿着埃文河来到巨石阵，那里的蓝石已经屹立了几个世纪。
纳什和他的同事们使用便携式X射线荧光检查了巨石阵所有52只沙鼠(曾经矗立在该遗址的80只沙鼠中唯一的幸存者)的化学成分。每种元素在受到X射线照射时发出的光波长略有不同，通过测量这些发射，研究人员可以绘制出一个物体的成分图，而不会损坏它。其中50个莎士比亚的化学指纹非常相似，这意味着它们很可能都来自同一个地方。由于这50名沙皇包括斯通58，他们很可能都来自西伍兹。
另外两只幸存的萨纳来自两个不同的地方，考古学家们还没有确定这一点。纳什和他的同事们说，可以接触到不同石头来源的不同社区可能是捐赠的石头，这些社区可能带来了一些现在从纪念碑中消失的莎草。“但我们可能永远不会知道，”他们写道。
尽管丢失了石头(双关语)，但这50个莎士比亚组成了巨石阵的不同部分，但它们都来自同一个地方。这意味着人们可能在大约同一时间建造了外部的萨森环，中央的马蹄形，以及像屠宰石和车站石这样的单独的石头，可能是在公元前2500年左右的第二阶段建造的。
这项研究还提出了一些新的问题，比如为什么有这么多萨森来源可供选择的新石器时代的人会特别去一个地点。纳什和他的同事们写道：“为什么在英国现存萨森石密度最高的地区，西伍德被选为巨石阵的主要来源尚不清楚。”他们认为，西森林可能提供了比其他遗址更大或质量更好的石头，或者它的位置可能使巨石更容易运输到巨石阵。
和往常一样，还有更多的工作要做，还有更多的证据需要寻找。纳什和他的同事们写道：“现在需要进行考古调查，并对西森林和周边地区的莎草进行进一步的详细采样，以更严格地限制确切的来源区域，并确定史前萨森采掘坑。”
note_en:
The huge slabs of stone that make up the most iconic structures at Stonehenge came from about 25km away, according to chemical analysis. Since the 1500s, most Stonehenge scholars have assumed the 6- to 7-meter tall, 20 metric ton sarsen stones came from nearby Marlborough Downs, and a recent study, by University of Brighton archaeologist David Nash and his colleagues, has now confirmed that.
  Recent studies have  traced Stonehenge’s bluestones to quarries in the Preseli Hills of western Wales, about 300km (200 miles) away. When another group of archaeologists studied the chemical isotope ratios in the cremated remains of people once buried beneath the bluestones, those researchers found that many of those people  may have come from the same part of Wales between 3100 and 2400 BCE. Ancient builders set up the sarsen stones a few centuries after the arrival of the bluestones. Modern scholars have only been able to speculate about where the huge boulders came from—until now.
 Sarsen, also called silcrete, is a sedimentary rock mostly made up of quartz sand cemented by silica (quartz is just silica in crystal form), formed in layers of sandy sediment. Thanks to erosion, sarsen boulders are now scattered in clumps all over southern England. Prehistoric Britons built monuments like Stonehenge and Avebury with sarsen boulders, Roman settlers used sarsen bricks to build their villas, and medieval people built sarsen churches and farm buildings. But the largest sarsen boulders we know of in Britain today are the ones at Stonehenge.
 About 99 percent of the average sarsen boulder is silica, but the other 1 percent contains trace amounts of other elements, like aluminum, calcium, iron, potassium, magnesium, and others. That extra material is different in different sarsen sources, as it depends on the minerals in the ground where the rock formed. Nash and his colleagues used those trace elements as a geochemical fingerprint to match the Stonehenge sarsens to their most likely source.
 The largest concentration of sarsen in the UK is at Marlborough Downs, an area of round, grassy hills 25 to 30km (17 miles) north of Stonehenge. Centuries of archaeologists and antiquarians have assumed the Stonehenge sarsens came from the Marlborough Downs, mostly because the area is nearby and full of the right material. But that idea hadn’t been scientifically tested, and the bluestones demonstrate that the Neolithic people who build Stonehenge had a far-flung and complex supply network—and their own reasons for doing things, often inscrutable to modern researchers.
  To track down the source of the sarsens, archaeologists first had to solve a more recent mystery: what happened to three missing chunks of Stonehenge?
 One of the trilithons (arch-like structures made of two upright stones supporting a horizontal lintel stone) in the central horseshoe fell down in 1797. A century and a half later, in 1958, a restoration project set the massive stones in place again—but one of the uprights, called Stone 58, had cracked along its length. To help hold the cracked stone together so it could stand and support its half of the lintel stone, restorers drilled three holes through the stone and inserted metal ties. After the project, the three stone cores they’d drilled out seemed to vanish into thin air.
 In 2018, one of the restorers, Robert Phillips, returned a broken but complete core from Stone 58 to the UK. Part of a second core turned up in the Salisbury Museum in 2019, but one and a half of the stone cores are still out there somewhere. Samples from the Phillips core gave Nash and his colleagues the chance to compare the chemical makeup of Stone 58 to sarsen boulders from sites all over Britain.
  The match turned out to be exactly what various researchers had assumed for the last 500 years. The only boulders that matched Stone 58 came from one site in the southeastern Marlborough Downs: West Woods, in Wiltshire, about 25km (16 miles) north of Stonehenge and just 3km (2 miles) south of where most studies had looked for Neolithic sarsen quarries. West Woods is a 6 square kilometer (4 square mile) plateau, partially wooded and dotted with large sarsen boulders and pits from millennia of quarrying.
 “West Woods lies within a concentration of Early Neolithic activity, being close to Avebury, numerous long barrows, and the causewayed enclosures at Knapp Hill,” wrote Nash and his colleagues. Thousands of years ago, many of the woods were open farmland which probably fed the same people who built Stonehenge and Avebury and  feasted at nearby Durrington Walls. From West Woods, ancient builders probably  hauled the sarsens down into the Vale of Pewsey and along the River Avon to Stonehenge, where the bluestones had already stood for centuries.
 Nash and his colleagues used portable X-ray fluorescence to check the chemical makeup of all 52 sarsens at Stonehenge (the only survivors of the 80 sarsens that once stood at the site). Each element emits a slightly different wavelength of light when hit by X-rays, and by measuring those emissions, researchers can map the composition of an object without damaging it. Fifty of the sarsens shared very similar chemical fingerprints, which means they probably all came from the same place. And since those 50 sarsens included Stone 58, it’s likely that they all came from West Woods.
 The other two surviving sarsens came from two different places, which archaeologists haven’t pinpointed yet. Nash and his colleagues say different communities with access to different stone sources may have been contributed stones, and those communities may have brought some of the sarsens now missing from the monument. “But we will probably never know,” they wrote.
  Missing stones notwithstanding (pun intended), the 50 sarsens made up different sections of Stonehenge, but they all came from the same place. That means that people probably built the outer Sarsen Circle, the Central Horseshoe, and the individual stones like the Slaughter Stone and Station Stones at around the same time, probably during the second phase of construction around 2500 BCE.
 The study also raises some new questions, such as why Neolithic people who had so many sarsen sources to select from would go to one site in particular. “Why, in a region with the greatest density of extant sarsen stones in Britain, West Wood was selected as the primary source for the Stonehenge sarsens is unclear,” Nash and his colleagues wrote. They suggest that West Woods may have offered larger or better quality stones than other sites, or that its location may have made it easier to transport the boulders to Stonehenge.
 As always, there’s more work to be done and more evidence to look for. “Archaeological investigations and further detailed sampling of sarsens from West Woods and surrounding areas are now required to more tightly constrain the precise source areas and identify prehistoric sarsen extraction pits,” wrote Nash and his colleagues.

或许立体主义者是对的。研究人员发现，当从冰山到岩石的一切都破碎时，它们的碎片往往像立方体。这一发现表明了从微观到行星尺度上碎裂的普遍规律。
“这是纯数学、材料科学和地质学的完美结合，”没有参与这项工作的普林斯顿大学化学和生物工程师苏吉特·达塔(Sujit Datta)说。
这一发现是建立在布达佩斯科技经济大学数学家加博尔·多莫科斯(Gábor Domokos)之前的工作基础上的，他在2006年帮助证明了戈姆博克(Gömböc)的存在，这是一种宝石状的形状，只有一个稳定的平衡点。把Gömböc放在桌子上，它总是会停在完全相同的位置，而不像圆柱体那样，可以侧卧或端卧。在随后的工作中，多莫科斯和他的同事们发现，诸如冲刷下游的鹅卵石和随风吹来的沙粒等实体往往会朝着GömböCISH形状侵蚀，但从未实现过这一理想。多莫科斯说：“戈姆伯克是大自然的一部分，但只是一个梦。”
然后，他和他的团队转向这个过程的另一边-岩石本身是如何诞生的。他们开始了他们的研究，在计算机模拟中将一个抽象的立方体“碎片化”，方法是用随机角度插入的50个2D平面将其切片。平面将立方体切割成60万个碎片，这些碎片本身平均为立方体-这意味着，平均而言，碎片有六个边是四边形，尽管任何单个碎片都不一定是立方体。这一结果让研究人员怀疑立方体可能是碎片化的共同特征。
研究人员试图通过真实世界的测量来证实这一预感。他们前往匈牙利布达佩斯Hármashatáhegy山的矿物白云岩露头，并计算了石面裂缝中的顶点数量。这些裂缝大多形成方形形状，这是立方体的面之一，无论它们是自然风化还是人类炸毁山体造成的。
最后，该团队创建了更强大的超级计算机模拟，模拟在理想化条件下3D材料的破裂-比如向所有方向均匀拉动一块岩石。这些案例形成的多面体碎片，在平均意义上是立方体，研究人员本周在美国国家科学院院刊(The Proceases Of The National Academy Of Sciences)上报道。
怀疑论者可能会指出，自然界中的许多东西都不会碎裂成立方体。例如，像云母这样的矿物会剥落成片状，而包括北爱尔兰巨人堤道在内的玄武岩地层则会破碎成六角柱状。
宾夕法尼亚大学(University Of Pennsylvania)地球物理学家、这篇论文的合著者道格拉斯·杰罗马克(Douglas Jerolmack)说，这是因为真正的材料不像团队模拟中发现的理想化形式。它们通常包含有利于非立方体破坏的内部结构或特性。例如，云母之所以会片状，是因为它在一个方向上比垂直方向弱。杰罗马克说：“但从统计平均意义上讲，岩石生来就是立方体的模糊影子。”他补充说，这些发现可以帮助水文学家预测流体通过地面裂缝开采石油的流动，或者帮助地质学家计算脱离悬崖表面的危险岩石的大小。
然而，一些人发现这项研究有点难以解析。德国地球科学研究中心的地质学家安妮·沃格特兰德(Anne Voigtländer)说：“你需要对地球表面过程有这种抽象的理论观点，才能真正挖掘出这可能意味着什么。”“地质学家有时很难理解它的价值，也很难看出它在哪里适用。”
杰罗马克同意，在某种意义上，结果更多的是哲学上的，而不是科学上的。他指出，他的团队从希腊哲学家柏拉图那里获得了灵感，柏拉图将四个经典元素-土、空气、火和水-都与一个规则的多面体联系在一起，巧合地将地球与立方体联系在一起。但柏拉图更为人铭记的是他对洞穴的寓言，在他的寓言中，他推测了某些理想化的和永恒的形式，这些形式在现实世界中只存在于乱码的版本中。“用肉眼可以看到扭曲的图像--碎片，”多莫科斯说。“但要看到理想，你必须动动脑筋。”
note_en:
Perhaps the Cubists were right. Researchers have found that when everything from icebergs to rocks breaks apart, their pieces tend to resemble cubes. The finding suggests a universal rule of fragmentation at scales ranging from the microscopic to the planetary.
 “It’s a very beautiful combination of pure mathematics, materials science, and geology,” says Sujit Datta, a chemical and biological engineer at Princeton University who was not involved in the work.
 The finding builds on the previous work of mathematician Gábor Domokos of Budapest University of Technology and Economics, who in 2006 helped prove the existence of the gömböc, a gemstonelike shape that has only one stable balance point. Set a gömböc down on a table, and it will always come to rest in the exact same position, unlike, say, a cylinder, which can rest on its end or its side. In subsequent work, Domokos and his colleagues found that entities such as pebbles washing downriver and sand grains blowing in the wind tend to erode toward gömböcish shapes without ever achieving that ideal. “The gömböc is part of nature, but only as a dream,” Domokos says.
 He and his team then turned to the other side of this process—how rocks themselves are born. They started their study “fragmenting” an abstract cube in a computer simulation by slicing it with 50 2D planes inserted at random angles. The planes cut the cube into 600,000 fragments, which were, on average, cubic themselves—meaning that, on average, the fragments had six sides that were quadrangles, although any individual fragment need not be a cube. The result led the researchers to suspect that cubes might be a common feature of fragmentation.
 The researchers tried to confirm this hunch using real-world measurements. They headed to an outcrop of the mineral dolomite on the mountain Hármashatárhegy in Budapest, Hungary, and counted the number of vertices in cracks in the stone face. Most of these cracks formed squarish shapes, which is one of the faces of a cube, regardless of whether they had been weathered naturally or had been created by humans dynamiting the mountain.
 Finally, the team created more powerful supercomputer simulations modeling the breakup of 3D materials under idealized conditions—like a rock being pulled equally in all directions.  Such cases formed polyhedral pieces that were, in an average sense, cubes, the researchers report this week in the  Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
 Skeptics might point out that many things in the natural world don’t fragment into cubes. Minerals such as mica, for instance, come off in flakes, whereas basaltic formations including the Giant’s Causeway in Northern Ireland break into hexagonal columns.
 That’s because real materials are not like the idealized forms found in the team’s simulations, says Douglas Jerolmack, a geophysicist at the University of Pennsylvania and co-author of the paper. They usually contain interior structures or properties that favor noncubic breakages. For example, mica flakes because it is weaker in one direction than in the perpendicular directions. “But in a statistical averaged sense, rocks are born as something that’s a vague shadow of a cube,” Jerolmack says. The findings, he adds, could help hydrologists predict fluid flow through cracks in the ground for oil extraction, or help geologists calculate the sizes of hazardous rocks breaking off cliff faces.
 Some find the study a bit difficult to parse, however. “You need to have this abstract theoretical view of earth surface processes to really dig into what this can mean,” says Anne Voigtländer, a geologist at the  GFZ German Research Centre for Geosciences. “It’s sometimes hard for geologists to understand the value of it, or to see where it applies.”
 Jerolmack agrees that, in some sense, the result is more philosophical than scientific. He notes that his team took inspiration from the Greek philosopher Plato, who related each of the four classical elements—earth, air, fire, and water—to a regular polyhedron, coincidentally linking earth with the cube. But Plato is more remembered for his allegory of the cave, in which he speculated about certain idealized and eternal forms, of which only garbled versions existed in the real world. “With the naked eye you see distorted images—the fragments,” Domokos says. “But in order to see the ideal, you have to use your mind.”
title: 从岩石到冰山，自然界往往会分裂成立方体。
title_en: From rocks to icebergs, the natural world tends to break into cubes

新加坡一直在努力吸引家族理财室，努力成为亚洲领先的财富管理中心。家族理财室是由世界上最富有的家族设立的秘密公司，用来管理他们的财富和利益，跨越几代人。税收优惠、专项基金结构和居住权承诺都已经部署完毕。

(Bloomberg) -- The world’s rich, reminded of their own mortality, are setting up family offices in greater numbers and plumping for Singapore as a base, according to  Monetary Authority of Singapore Deputy Director  Spencer Hsu.
       “It appears the pandemic has actually served as a reminder of individual mortality and prompted families to bring forward plans, which they may have cast aside previously,” Hsu, who’s also part of the central bank’s family office development team, said during a  virtual forum in the city-state Wednesday.
    Singapore has been trying to attract family offices -- the secretive firms set up by the world’s richest clans to manage their money and interests across multiple generations -- in an effort to become Asia’s leading wealth management hub. Tax incentives, special fund structures and promises of residency have all been deployed.
 Family offices on the island increased fivefold between 2017 and 2019, Hsu said, without indicating what the figures have been like so far in 2020. That’s an acceleration versus previously disclosed growth figures. MAS doesn’t publicly release the overall number of family offices in the city-state.
 “Because families are spending more time at home, they have more time to think about setting up their family offices and as such, we see that the trend of growth is likely to persist,” he said.
 MAS and the Singapore Economic Development Board  formed the family office development team last year.
 One initiative is the  global investor program, which helps the key beneficiaries of family offices with at least S$200 million ($145 million) under management get on a pathway to permanent residence status. Tax exemptions can also be used to offset some profits on stocks and derivatives.
 Some well-known rich people who have put down roots in Singapore include Facebook Inc. co-founder Eduardo Saverin and vacuum cleaner designer James Dyson.

The new, higher-energy dense 2170 cells will be produced by  Panasonic   at Tesla’s factory in Sparks, Nevada, the company said Thursday. Panasonic is upgrading its battery cell lines with production slated to begin in September. The company operates 13 lines at the factory with a capacity to produce 35 gigawatt hours of batteries each year. All 13 lines will eventually run the new technology, Panasonic Energy North America President Allan Swan said without providing a timeline of when the entire system would be upgraded.
 “We’re about to take another leap forward,” Swan said in a recent interview. “It’s kind of exciting from the Panasonic perspective; we’re driving towards cobalt free and we’re driving towards higher energy dense batteries, which gives our customers a choice of how they want utilize that.”
  The facility where these new battery cells will be produced is known as Gigafactory 1,  a critical component of Tesla’s plan to expand global battery capacity and reduce the cost of electric vehicles. Panasonic has been its most important partner in that project, which based  on a recent agreement should last until at least 2023. Panasonic makes the 2170 cells at Gigafactory 1, which Tesla then uses to make battery packs for the Model 3. The 2170 cells are also used in  Tesla’s   newest vehicle, the Model Y.
 Here’s a quick primer. A battery contains two electrodes. There’s an anode (negative) on one side and a cathode (positive) on the other. An electrolyte sits in the middle and acts as the courier that moves ions between the electrodes when charging and discharging.
 A cell with greater energy density means that engineers figured out a way to pack more energy in that space. The 5% improvement in energy density in the cells should result in the same gains in Tesla’s battery packs. The upshot: Tesla’s Model 3 and Model Y could see improvements in range. The reduction in cobalt content, a rare chemical element that is expensive and has social and environmental costs, could also help reduce the price of the cells.
 Panasonic’s factories in Japan produce the cylindrical lithium-ion “18650” cells, which are used to power Tesla’s Model S and Model X vehicles. Panasonic has already improved 18650 cells, resulting in a reduction in cobalt and improvement in energy density.
 Panasonic uses a NCA, or nickel-cobalt-aluminium, cathode chemistry in its battery cells. Panasonic wouldn’t disclose the amount of cobalt used today or get into the details of its technology. However, Celina Mikolajczak, vice president of battery technology at Panasonic Energy of North America, did say that the total amount of cobalt used in Panasonic cylindrical automotive batteries is less than 2% of global demand.
 Mikolajczak said that NCA uses less cobalt than NCM, or nickel manganese cobalt oxide. The NCA cathode chemistry has been further developed to reduce cobalt, she added .
 The company is aiming for zero cobalt in its battery cells, Mikolajczak said. Panasonic has already managed that feat in its R&D lab. The  plan is to commercialize cobalt-free batteries in a few years.

在新冠肺炎大流行之前，Quora有着浓厚的办公室文化，大部分时间都不鼓励员工远程工作。但一旦公司别无选择，Quora首席执行官兼联合创始人亚当·D‘Angelo表示，他们发现在任何地方工作的好处远远大于缺点。就在几周前，Quora宣布它将成为一家远程第一公司。这一政策将超越对面对面聚会的任何公共卫生限制，Quora的办公室将更多地作为希望回到办公室的员工的共同工作空间，而不是公司的中央总部。
Greylock普通合伙人大卫·萨克与亚当坐下来讨论了他做出这一影响深远的改变的决定，这一转变对Quora的生产力和文化产生了什么影响，以及他认为远程工作将如何让社会变得更好。本期“灰色物质”是一个新系列的一部分，该系列关注的是使随时随地工作成为可能的人员、技术和政策。
“我们创办这家公司时，那是一个非常不同的时期。让每个人都在办公室是很有意义的。与现在相比，硅谷的住房成本相当低，很容易获得H1B签证，来自世界各地的人很容易来到这里，很容易将所有人聚集在一个地方，办公空间也很便宜。所以我们只会时不时地看看这个，在那里我们会尝试远程工作。而且似乎偏僻的人总是处于劣势。但实际上，每个人都处于劣势，因为你最终不得不用两种方式做每一件事。“。
“如果有人在远程工作，与办公室里的人相比，他们总是错过了机会。假设你正在开会，所有人都在办公室，只有一个人在打视频电话。一开始还不错，但后来每个人都会把它们忘得一干二净。他们看不到每个人的脸。他们很难引起人们的注意。因此，他们最终感觉与外界脱节，然后随着时间的推移，他们有点像被视为二等团队成员。这些都不是恶意的，也不是故意的，但人们倾向于偏向身边的人，偏向他们每天看到的人。“。
“当你们并不都在同一系统上运营时，要经营一家公司，让每个人都朝着同一个方向发展，这已经够难的了。在很长一段时间里，情况就是这样，因为我们已经转向开放的办公室计划，以及大量的会议和互动时刻。因此，办公室有建立关系和做出选择的正常方式，那些不在办公室的人就是没有这样的方式。“。
自从Quora开始在家工作以来，你看到了什么改变了你的想法？
“人们工作效率很高，很多人实际上更喜欢在家工作。他们不必担心通勤，他们可以住的地方不受限制，他们不必担心办公室的安全。每个人都站在同一立场上，因为这不是办公室里的人和远程的人的混合。每个人都有同样的优势。“。
“到目前为止，我们能够大致维持同样的流程。我们设定目标，我们开会，我们保持同步。我们测试过很多东西，我们做了大量的实验。所有这些都在继续发挥作用。我们依赖很多内部工具来进行实验和持续部署我们的代码。但到目前为止，它还没有发生太大的变化。“
“我们非常关注同步通信。我们使用Zoom进行视频通话，而且我们做了很多这样的事情。我们认为，拥有不同技能和不同职责的人之间的来回交流是非常重要的。我们意识到，你必须把所有事情都写下来，并将所有事情正式化为结构化的目标，这会限制创造力，也会限制你突破可能的界限的能力。“。
“适应新环境的挑战是试图复制办公室周围发生的一些非正式沟通。这是我现在特别感兴趣的一个领域。“。
“特别是在这一点上，我们的大多数员工都表示，他们不愿回到办公室。但仍有相当一部分员工真正喜欢办公室-他们想要社交，也许他们家里没有空间让他们高效地工作，或者他们有孩子，他们想在家庭和工作之间划出一些界限。因此，在我们这样做的同时，我们对员工进行了一系列调查，询问诸如“你觉得自己的工作效率有多高？”“我们能做些什么来提高你的工作效率呢？”‘你想从我们这里知道些什么？’“。
您如何决定采用坚定的远程优先策略，而不是静观其变？
“首先，我认为每个人都真的从果断中受益。我从其他公司的许多员工那里听说，不确定性正在杀死每个人。没有人知道他们是否必须回到办公室，他们不知道他们是否可以搬出旧金山湾区，他们不知道他们的孩子是否会重返学校，他们的租约即将到期，他们必须想好下一步的行动，等等。但他们的公司仍然没有给出明确的指导，或者他们提供的指导不断变化-就像他们现在很遥远，但然后他们可能会回到办公室-首先，但他们不知道什么时候，或者他们没有给出明确的答案，关于什么是混合动力。或者人们是否会倾向于由在位的人来执政。当人们不知道该怎么做时，整个事情可能很快就会瓦解。“。
您为什么决定实施远程优先策略，而不是办公室内和远程的混合策略？
“在混合模式下，很多事情都可能出错，因为你总是会从办公室里获得一点优势。”这可能只是因为你的老板在那里，你可以通过面对面地与他们在一起，与他们建立更牢固的关系。或者可能会有问题，因为人们可能有一种习惯，即根据某人是否出现在他们面前，以及他们有多频繁地对他们的工作进行微妙的判断。在办公室里，你可以更容易地证明你真的很努力。但是如果你在远程，人们就不能确切地看到你工作了多少。我认为，事情真的倾向于从首席执行官那里慢慢向下渗透。如果首席执行官在那里，那么其他最有抱负、想要与他们建立关系的人都会认为，他们最有可能做到这一点的是在办公室里。
你在过去学到的哪些经验教训帮助你适应了当前的情况？
“我明白了，你真的必须果断行事。当我们在2009年成立这家公司时，就在移动和智能手机采用的大浪潮来袭之前。我们并不是真的把移动作为一个机会-我们试图逐渐适应它。我们有一些自下而上的努力，我们有一个移动团队，我们有专门为不同平台开发移动应用的人员，等等。但我们从来没有真正在高层说过，‘嘿，这真的很重要，我们真的需要做出艰难的决定，并围绕这些决定来引导公司。’我们最终适应了它，但它花了比它应该花的时间长得多的时间。回想起来，我认为作为首席执行官，我首先需要认识到那个决定是多么关键，做出一个选择是多么重要，然后我需要站出来，在一段时间内把它作为每个人的首要任务。我需要几乎愿意把这个选择强加给每个人，即使这是一个艰难的选择。“。
你认为当前这段时间将如何改变未来的工作场所政策？
“我认为很多员工已经认识到，他们更喜欢在家工作，即使他们过去不想为远程优先的公司工作。但现在他们有了这样的经历，并知道它是有效的。这是一个巨大的变化，因为你现在可以更容易地招聘到更好的员工，仅仅因为想要远程工作的人的市场可能已经大幅增长。我认为投资者看到这些公司做得很好，尽管它们距离很远。在过去，为一家以远程为导向的公司筹集资金可能会更困难。我看到了对GitLab首席执行官的采访，他说，在他们存在的大部分时间里，投资者认为他们很遥远这一事实是负面的。这会破坏每个人对公司成功的信心。所以我认为，现在所有人都看到在家工作真的可以很好地工作，这一点已经完全改变了。“。
“我们之所以做出这样的选择，是因为我们认为这对我们和我们的员工以及我们的使命来说都是最好的。但我认为，随着越来越多的公司面向远程工作，这将给世界和社会带来大量好处。其中一大成本就是通勤。旧金山湾区的人们单程通勤大约要花一个小时，这段时间基本上都被浪费了。我感兴趣的另一个动态是美国的劳动力流动问题：如果你看看20世纪40年代和50年代的数据，你会发现人们过去在全国各地流动的次数比现在多得多。他们过去常常搬到可以赚更多钱的地方，所以人均GDP较高的州通常会有人口流入，而人们只会离开人均GDP较低的州。所以人们会去他们能赚更多钱的地方，这对每个人都有好处。但这意味着每个人都去同样的地方，现在我们面临的所有问题都是：住房成本高，工作地点拥挤，其他地区没有机会。“。
“如果你是一对远程工作的夫妇中的一员，突然之间，整个协调问题就消失了。每个伴侣都可以接受任何最好的工作，这对夫妇可以搬到对他们最合适的任何地方。您甚至不需要整个员工远程工作就可以获得这项福利。我们可以回到过去的劳动力流动水平，这将减轻高成本住房市场的压力。
“很多员工不得不面临一个选择，要么呆在一个地方，要么四处走动，但没有办公室员工那样的优势。因此，我认为Remote-First将给我们提供一个公平的竞争环境，因为它会告诉我们，无论你在世界上的哪个地方，你都会在你的工作中与其他所有人平起平坐。这将使人们可以自由地去做对他们最有利的事情，不仅是为了工作，也是为了他们在余生中所珍视的任何事情。“
note_en:
Prior to the Covid-19 pandemic, Quora had a strong office culture and discouraged employees from working remotely most of the time. But once the company had no choice, Quora CEO and co-founder Adam D’Angelo says they discovered the benefits of working from anywhere far outweigh the drawbacks. Just a few weeks ago,  Quora announced it would become a remote first company. That policy will extend beyond any public health restrictions on in-person gatherings, and Quora’s office will function more as a co-working space for employees who wish to return to the office rather than as the company’s central headquarters.
 Greylock general partner David Thacker sat down with Adam to discuss his decision to make this far-reaching change, what impact the shift has made on Quora’s productivity and culture, and how he thinks remote working will change society for the better. This episode of Greymatter is part of a  new series focusing on the people, technologies and policies that are making working from anywhere possible.
      “It was a very different time when we started the company. It just made sense to have everyone in the office. Housing costs in Silicon Valley were pretty low relative to what they are now, it was easy to get H1B visas and easy for people from around the world to get here, it was easy to assemble everyone in one place and office space was cheap. So we would only look at this from time to time, where we would experiment with remote work. And it always seemed like people who were remote were at a disadvantage. But actually, everyone was at a disadvantage because you end up having to do everything two ways.”
 “If someone was working remotely, they were always missing out compared to those who were in the office. Say you were having a meeting and everyone was in the office except one person, who is on a video call. It’s fine at first, but then everyone tends to kind of forget about them. They can’t see everyone’s faces. It’s hard for them to get people’s attention. So they end up feeling disconnected, and then over time they kind of become regarded as a second-class team member. None of this is malicious or intentional, but people tend to have a bias toward whoever is right next to them and who they are seeing every day.”
 “It’s hard enough to run a company and get everyone going in the same direction when you aren’t all operating on the same system. And for a long time, that’s how it has been because we’ve moved toward open office plans and lots of meetings and moments for interactions. So the office had the normal way of building relationships and making choices, those who weren’t there just didn’t have that.”
 What have you seen since Quora has been working from home that has changed your mind?
 “People are very productive and a lot of them actually prefer working from home. They don’t have to worry about a commute, they aren’t limited in where they can live, they don’t have to worry about the safety of the office. And everyone is on the same page because it’s not a mix of people in the office and people remote. Everyone has the same advantage.”
  “So far we’ve been able to roughly maintain the same process. We set goals, we have meetings, we stay in sync. We test things out, we’ve run a ton of experiments. All of that has continued to work. We rely on a lot of in-house tools for things like experimentation and continuous deployment of our code. But so far it hasn’t had to change too much.”
 “We’re very focused on synchronous communication. We use Zoom for video calls and we do a lot of them. And we think that the kind of back and forth between people who have different skill sets and different responsibilities is very important. We realize you have to write absolutely everything down and formalize everything into, you know, structured goals, that’s going to limit creativity and it’s going to limit the ability to kind of push the boundaries of what’s possible.”
  “What’s been challenging in adapting to the new environment is trying to replicate some of the informal communication that happened around the office. It’s an area I’m particularly interested in right now.”
 “Especially at this point, when the majority of our employees are saying they would prefer not to come back to the office. But there is still a significant fraction of the employees who really liked the office – they want to socialize, maybe they don’t have space at home to work super productively, or maybe they have kids and they want to have some boundary between home and work. So as we are doing this, we’ve run a series of surveys of employees asking things like, ‘How productive do you feel like you’ve been?’ ‘What can we do to make you more productive?’ ‘What would you like to know from us?’”
 How did you decide to adopt a firm remote-first policy, rather than waiting and seeing how this plays out?
 “First, I think everyone really benefits from being decisive. I’ve heard from a lot of employees at other companies that the uncertainty is killing everyone. No one knows if they are going to have to go back to their office or not, they don’t know if they can move out of the Bay Area, they don’t know if their kids are going to be back in school, their lease is almost up and they have to figure out their next move, etc. But their company still hasn’t given clear guidance, or they give guidance that keeps changing – like they are remote for now, but then they will probably go back to office-first, but they don’t know when, or they don’t give a clear answer on what the hybrid model will look like, or whether it will be preferred for people to be in-office. And when people don’t know what to do, the whole thing can unravel pretty quickly.”
 Why did you decide to put a remote-first policy in place, rather than a hybrid of in-office and remote?
 “With a hybrid set-up, a lot can go wrong because you are always going to get a little bit of an advantage from being at the office. And that could just be because your boss is there and you can build a stronger relationship with them by being right next to them, in-person. Or there can be an issue because people might be in the habit of subtly judging someone’s work based on whether they are there in front of them, and how often. In the office, you can more easily demonstrate that you work really hard. But if you are remote, people can’t see exactly how much you’re working. I think things really tend to trickle down from the CEO. If the CEO is there, then the most ambitious other people who want to build relationships with them, will assume that their best chance at that is by being in the office.”
 What are some of the lessons you’ve learned in the past that have helped you adapt to the current situation?
 “I learned that you really have to be decisive. When we started the company in 2009, it was just before the big wave of mobile and smartphone adoption hit. And we didn’t really jump on mobile as an opportunity – we tried to gradually adapt to it. There were some bottom up efforts, we had a mobile team, we had individuals working on mobile apps for different platforms, etc. But we never really said at a high level, ‘Hey, this is really important and we really need to make tough decisions and orient the company around them.’ We eventually adapted to it, but it took a lot longer than it should have. In retrospect, I think as CEO I needed to first recognize how critical that decision was and how important it was to make a choice, and then I needed to stand up and make it everyone’s top priority for some period of time. I needed to be willing to almost impose that choice on everyone, even though it was a tough choice to make.”
 How do you think this current period in time will change workplace policies going forward?
 “I think a lot of employees have learned that they prefer working from home, even if they wouldn’t have wanted to work for a remote-first company in the past. But now they’ve had this experience and know it works. That’s a big change going forward in that you can now more easily recruit better employees, just because the market for people who want to work remotely has probably grown massively. And I think investors are seeing these companies do well despite the fact that they are remote. In the past, it might’ve been harder to raise money for a company that was remote-oriented. I saw an interview with the Gitlab CEO who said that for most of their existence, investors saw the fact that they were remote as a negative. It would undermine the process of everyone’s confidence in the success of the company. So I think that has totally changed now that everyone has seen that working from home can work really well.”
  “We made this choice because we think it’s the best thing for us and our employees and for our mission. But I think there are a ton of benefits that come to the world and to society as more companies orient around remote work. One big cost is just commuting. People in the Bay Area spend around an hour commuting each way, and that whole time is basically wasted. Another dynamic I’ve gotten interested in is this issue of labor mobility in the US: if you look at data from the 1940s and 1950s, people used to move around the country a lot more than they do now. They used to move toward locations where they could make more money, so the states that had higher GDP per capita would usually see inflows of population, and people would just leave the states with states with lower GDP per capita. So people would set out for where they could make more money, and that was good for everyone. But that means everyone goes to the same places and now you have all the issues we have right now: high housing costs and crowding where the jobs are, and no opportunities in the other regions.”
 “If you are part of a couple who is working remotely, suddenly this whole coordination problem is gone. Each partner can just take whatever the best job is, and the couple can relocate to wherever works best for them. You don’t even need the whole workforce working remotely to get this benefit. We can get back to the level of labor mobility we had in the past, and it will take pressure off the high-cost housing markets.
 “A lot of employees have had to face a choice of either stay in one location, or move around but not have the same advantages as those at the office. And so I think remote-first will give us this level playing field by saying wherever you are in the world, you’re going to be on even footing with everyone else at your job. It’s going to free people up to move around for whatever is best for them, not just for work but for whatever they value in the rest of their life.”
